title: Three arrested over £250,000 worth of illegal TV set-top boxes sold on social media
text:

Three people from Greater Manchester have been arrested during a crackdown on the sale of up to £250,000 worth of illegal TV set-top boxes. 
Officers raided six houses across the north west on Wednesday morning and arrested five people suspected of selling illegal devices. 
A 33-year-old man from Tameside, a 46-year-old man from Manchester and a 36-year-old woman from Cheadle were arrested at their homes by Greater Manchester Police. Read More 
Another two men, aged 60 and 36, from Bootle, were arrested by the City of London Police’s Intellectual Property Crime Unit (PIPCU) during the clampdown. 
Fully loaded illegal set-top devices were seized at the homes of five suspects. 
The set-top boxes were found to be pre-loaded with unlicensed add-ons and apps, which then allow users to illegally stream content to their television. 
This includes premium pay for TV channels, live sport and films. Read More The Kodi expert tips and hacks you need to know 
It is believed the suspects made in the region of £250,000 by selling the devices on social media sites, online forums as well as their own dedicated websites. 
All of the suspected were taken to police stations and have been released on bail pending further enquiries. 
The day of action was organised by the Federation Against Copyright Theft, who were supported by GMP, Merseyside Police and PIPCU officers. 
Kieron Sharp, Director General of FACT, said “Today’s day of action should send out a clear warning to anyone involved in the sale and distribution of illegal set-top boxes that law enforcement and industry take this matter very seriously.
